p: Further, the vernacular name manjerona-de-Angola has been documented before in Belém, but associated with Origanum majorana L. instead of Lippia thymoides [ 9]. A closely related plant, Lippia multiflora Moldenke, is used as medicine and in rituals along the western coast of Africa [ 78, 79]. We suggest that L. multiflora was replaced in use by L. thymoides in Belém, and it is possibly used in Afro-Brazilian ceremonies.
